PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.

A FEW PLAIN WORDS.

If Honore in his day came to bitterly complain of men soiled with the immoralities of the times, how much more are we to be pitied in our present state under the awful affliction of men suffering from the yet more innumerable itch of speaking we had almost permitted ourselves to use the expression half a dozen years past. Emotions of pride and disgust and amusement in turn dispel each other; as when sometimes happens, something with all the organs and more or less the soul of a man, at public meetings and solemnizing sound for some, behoves forth mighty nothing's legation of the very emptiness of his starved inside or outside. We stand there in public with a full knowledge of our own time and with an air determined as a slightly insignificant personal appearance admits of, pipe out "we must have so and so" and then the most extraordinary declaration that is from one point of view incredible amusing, and we would be hardly squandering such an object to deprive the public of so rare a treat as such a sight affords, especially when the exhibition comes without the self-respect of the exhibitor. Our desire is to speak a few plain words to men who, while very different from such as we have sufficiently in discussion, are not without their pretensions. By leaving up an irregular tenement in the Territories, discharging the value of property generally, we do it from us to be a word against the Government, and a word against constitutional notions, in obtaining a dress of grievances, which undoubtedly exist, and to assert our rights, but in order to do this we must talk, and talk in a loud manner. Such a protestation is to the mind of the majority of the world a monstrous thing to the State. Although it is contrary to the feelings of the vast majority of the people, it makes certain individuals think that the Government of Canada and British Columbia (not prepared for such a cause) in an appeal to the Crown for interposition from the Dominion, or even later on make this application on our behalf, would be a great loss to talk of a rebellion now is simply both. Supposing such an insurrection to be made, the Government has only to close the land offices, to stop the sale of our produce, to move the police, the soldiers, and other supplies to the limits, to discontinue our mail service, and remove the general machines of civil and governmental power, to bring us to know by the next morning. Meanwhile every idle threat of a disturbance reaching quarters where its real value is far from understood keeps our settlers and drives away capital, and we suspect that the Government is not in imagination. We grant this statement on the belief that were our reasonable requirements properly put before the Governmental authorities in their interest to do so, the question of the moment would go to Mr. Mahon, Mahon must go to the mountain so if it is too far for Sir John, or any Cabinet minister, to come to us,

G. D. NORTHGRAVES,

EDITORIAL NOTES.

An ingenious Frenchman proposes that Paris should have an artificial sun. He says there should be no night in Paris at all, and that the nights could be turned into days, and the Parisians enabled to drive about and to promenade under a sun of their own manufacture. There would be no difference between the best and worst parts of the city. The idea is that a tubular tower a fifth of a mile in height should be erected surrounded by a series of gigantic carbon points kept burning by a powerful current that would play upon the faces and bodies of two thousand citizens. Over this blinding ball of light he would put a movable reflector, large enough to throw the light over the whole city. It is said that when they looked at their watches to tell whether it was four o'clock in the morning or ten o'clock in the afternoon, but this difficulty could be eliminated by adopting the twenty-four hour clock time system.
